body: I'm also being impacted to this issue.

I agree that, if the credential helper returns a nonzero exit code, the helper response should be completely ignored (i.e., a subsequent request to the same URI should always call the helper again).

However, I'm not sure I understand this sentence:

> Furthermore, this caching of connection completely ignores the expiry provided to Bazel in the credential helper response.

Are you still talking about the case where the helper returns a nonzero exit code? Or are you saying that, *even if the helper returns exit code 0 and includes an expiry in the response*, the HTTP downloader will keep using the credentials for longer than the expiry? (I would consider that to be a separate issue.)
Yes, it is the latter.  If there is an expiry returned in the response (with exit status 0) then the credentials are continued to be used even past that expiry which results in a 401 response.

Alright. Just to make sure we're on the same page, the scenario you originally described, namely

```
Use a http_archive to download from a server that requires authentication. Provide the authentication through a credential_helper script. Provide invalid credentials on the first execution of Bazel (exit code 1). Update the script to provide the correct credentials (exit 0 with valid JSON). Note that Bazel still gets 401 from the download.
```

is not reproducible for me (i.e., the build succeeds after amending the credential helper to return a successful response). If this doesn't match what you see, please provide a more complete repro.

I haven't yet tried to reproduce the other scenario you described (successful credential helper response getting cached beyond the provided expiry) but I'll get to it next week.

There is indeed a bug that causes the expiry provided by a successful credential helper response to be incorrectly interpreted by Bazel (possibly resulting in the credentials expiring too soon, or too late). I'll have a fix submitted shortly.

Thank you, sorry I didn't reply before I haven't had chance to create a simple repro script as of yet and didn't think it was worth wasting your time with a no-op comment.  Pleased you managed to locate something never the less.

@chrisstaite-menlo I'm actually not sure that 459709e fixes the bug you described. If my understanding is correct, the bug was introduced in 82c1ff7, but that change was submitted after 8.x was cut, and never cherry-picked; so it doesn't make sense to cherry-pick this fix either.

Can I still trouble you for a self-contained repro so I can keep investigating (and be sure that I'm investigating the right issue)?
Sure, I'll try and generate a small repro next week.
